results.title: Food additives
results.creator_credit: Deborah Manners, Open Tafe, Box Hill College of Technical and Further Education and Shane Mulcahy
results.brief_description: A discussion with Dr. K. Farrer, author of “Fancy eating that” who describes the history of food additives and examines what is added and why. He also addresses the safety aspects of additives and regulations to control their use. Hosted by Peter Couchman.

results.title: Food (for) thought
results.creator_credit: Dennis Tupicoff, Victorian College of the Arts and Daniel Crooks
results.brief_description: Food. Religion. Television. Using a multiplicity of styles, this technically accomplished animation seeks to present a critique of religion and consumer culture. It makes an impressive idiosyncratic statement, with stylistic references to Jan Svankmajer and the Brothers Quay.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dennis Tupicoff, Victorian College of the Arts and Daniel Crooks

results.title: Fond memories of Cuba [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Film Finance Corporation Australia, Frontline Films and David Bradbury
results.brief_description: In this film about life in modern Cuba, documentary filmmaker David Bradbury travels across the country attempting to answer the question of whether Cuba has succeeded as a socialist society, forty years after Fidel Castro’s rise to power. “Fond memories of Cuba” is a telling testament to the daily struggle for survival for the inhabitants of Cuba, many of who lament their lot in life. The film depicts a decayed country that thrives on music and culture but is incapacitated financially and crippled by the US embargo. Despite many positive reviews, Bradbury was critiqued for imposing onto this project his disillusionment with Cuba and pre-ordained notion of a society in peril, which he then sought to confirm via this work. Essentially a collection of interviews, “Fond memories of Cuba” also features many street scenes including arrests that depict police brutality. This work is interspersed with archival footage of the 1960s revolution and pre-revolution political situation, which includes discussion of the role of Che Guevara during those times. As well as a document that teases out questions of politics and society, the film also serves as a fascinating travelogue of the country’s natural beauty and enduring culture. In English and Spanish with English subtitles.

results.title: Following the plough
results.brief_description: A tour of contemporary Canadian agriculture led by a modern troubador whose work on the land moves him to song. What is seen is farming as big business coast-to-coast, mechanised, automated, where the farmer is businessman, scientist, world citizen, but still a man with a desire for independence and his own place on the land.

results.title: Follow the leader
results.brief_description: A supervisory training film which makes use of puppets. Designed to increase employee pride in and identification with the organisation. It also aims to make employees understand and be proud of their job and their skill at performing it.

results.title: Follow my leader
results.brief_description: A Girl Guide Company requires a new leader. No-one is available so the Company carries on as best it can. Finally the Guides erect notices promoting a display of what they do and before too long they get a volunteer for a new leader and also new recruits.

group_works.title: The China teapot story: a Chinese legend
group_works.creator_credit: Wladislaw Neherbecki and Sterling Educational Films

results.title: Folk dancing is fun
results.creator_credit: John Kingsford-Smith, Kingcroft Productions and Evelyn McCloughan
results.brief_description: Illustrates the important part folk dancing can play in primary education. Shows the teaching of folk dancing in simple movements to young children, and a series of more complicated Latvian and French dances suitable for older children. Demonstrates how actual dancing can lead to activities such as class projects on national folk dances, costumes and music, and how this interest can lead to international understanding and correct social behaviour at an early stage. The film concludes with a school folk dancing festival complete with national costumes made by the children. Music by Barbara Mettam.

results.title: Folk dances today
results.creator_credit: F A Film Associates and Mario Casetto
results.brief_description: At a teenagers’ dance party it is the “in” thing to do Greek and Armenian line dances, the Swedish “hambo”, middle eastern “debkas”, and Bulgarian “kolos”. The film cuts away to show each ethnic dance, or type, performed by exhibition groups with authentic styling in national costumes.
